docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article yesterday about health plans and medical groups that pay doctors for e-mail consultations with patients misstated the number of doctors accepting online messages at the Palo Alto Medical Foundation in California. It is 300, not 69.

docs.lead_paragraph: Governors and the Bush administration agreed on Tuesday to intensify negotiations on ways to clamp down on Medicaid costs after four days of talks sputtered to an inconclusive end. Michael O. Leavitt, the secretary of health and human services, said he saw 8 to 10 ''areas of potential common ground'' with the governors.

headline.main: Governors And Officials Step Up Talks On Medicaid

docs.abstract: National Governors Association and Bush administration agree to intensify negotiations on ways to clamp down on Medicaid costs after four days of talks in Washington sputter to inconclusive end; Michael O Leavitt, secretary of health and human services, says he sees 8 to 10 areas of potential common ground with governors (S)
docs.snippet: The secretary of health and human services said he saw 8 to 10 "areas of potential common ground" with the governors on ways to clamp down on Medicaid costs.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's final. The tentative three-year contract that includes pay raises and more money for health plans for the two major Hollywood actors unions was overwhelmingly ratified on Monday night after nationwide mail-in voting ended. The 119,000 union members representing the combined membership of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists voted to accept the contract by a margin of 76.5 percent to 23.5, said Seth Oster, a spokesman for the Screen Actors Guild. ''We're very pleased that we were able to achieve some very important gains for working actors, and at the same time keep performers working for another three years uninterrupted,'' he said. The tentative deal with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers was reached on Jan. 20. Although the actors had hoped to win a larger share of DVD sales, the contract includes a 9 percent minimum pay raise over three years and the most employer money ever contributed to the unions' health and pension plans. There will also be 75,000 new jobs, the highest increase in 13 years, for background actors (known as extras). The contract will run from July 1, 2005, through June 30, 2008. CATHERINE BILLEY
docs.abstract: Arts, Briefly column; members of Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Television and Radio Artists overwhelmingly approve tentative three-year contract with Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers that includes pay raises and more money for health plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Behind Those Medical Malpractice Rates'' (Business Day, Feb. 22), you report that ''while claims are rising at a measured pace, there have been more headline-grabbing big awards.'' This is frustrating to physicians and patients living in states without medical liability reforms, where these big awards lead to skyrocketing medical liability insurance premiums, putting patient access to care at risk. Reforms that include a cap on pain and suffering stabilize premiums, which is why 73 percent of Americans support them.
docs.abstract: American Medical Assn Pres Dr John C Nelson letter says states with caps on pain and suffering awards have stabilized medical liability insurance premiums, whereas doctors in states without caps pay much more in malpractice insurance (Feb 22 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush told governors on Monday that he wanted to work with them to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid, the health insurance program for more than 50 million low-income people. But governors said they were far from reaching an agreement with the White House. ''We want Medicaid to work,'' Mr. Bush told the governors, who were visiting the White House as part of their winter conference. ''We also recognize that the system needs to be reformed, and we want to work with you to do so.''

headline.main: Governors Resist Bush's Appeal for Quick Deal on Medicaid

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, in appeal for quick agreement, tells group of governors visiting White House that he wants to work with them to curtail cost of Medicaid, but governors say they are not ready to reach agreement; Pres Bush has proposed cutting $60 billion from federal Medicaid spending over 10 years; governors want more discretion in deciding who receives benefits, but fear costs will be shifted to states without easing of federal requirements (M)
docs.snippet: President Bush told governors that he wanted to work with them to rein in the soaring cost of Medicaid.
